content.title: Anemia of Chronic Disease
content.summary: Anemia of chronic disease (ACD), also termed anemia of inflammation, is a hypoproliferative anemia occurring in the setting of chronic inflammatory conditions, infections, or malignancies. It is characterized by impaired iron utilization despite adequate iron stores, mediated primarily through hepcidin-induced iron sequestration.
key_points: Second most common anemia worldwide after iron deficiency
Hepcidin is the central mediator blocking iron release from macrophages
Normal or elevated ferritin distinguishes from iron deficiency anemia
Low serum iron with low TIBC (vs high TIBC in iron deficiency)
Treatment focuses on underlying disease; erythropoietin may help
content.statement: Anemia of chronic disease is a cytokine-mediated hypoproliferative anemia characterized by impaired iron utilization, decreased erythropoietin production, and shortened red blood cell survival, occurring secondary to chronic inflammatory, infectious, or neoplastic conditions.

explanation.intuition: Think of ACD as the body hoarding iron in storage cells during illness - an evolutionary protective mechanism to starve pathogens of iron, but which inadvertently causes anemia by limiting iron availability for red blood cell production.
explanation.key_insight: The distinguishing feature is that iron is trapped in macrophages rather than truly deficient. Hepcidin, induced by IL-6, blocks ferroportin and prevents iron export from enterocytes and macrophages.
explanation.technical_details: Pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-1β, TNF-α) increase hepcidin synthesis via STAT3 pathway. Hepcidin binds ferroportin causing its internalization and degradation. This reduces iron absorption and iron release from macrophages. Additionally, cytokines blunt erythropoietin response and reduce RBC survival.

definitions_glossary.hepcidin: A 25-amino acid peptide hormone produced by hepatocytes that is the master regulator of iron homeostasis; it reduces iron availability by degrading ferroportin
definitions_glossary.ferroportin: The only known mammalian cellular iron exporter, expressed on enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes
definitions_glossary.transferrin_saturation: The ratio of serum iron to total iron-binding capacity, typically low in both ACD and iron deficiency
definitions_glossary.ferritin: The major iron storage protein; elevated or normal in ACD despite functional iron deficiency
definitions_glossary.TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity, reflects transferrin levels; low-normal in ACD but high in iron deficiency
definitions_glossary.hypoproliferative_anemia: Anemia characterized by inadequate red blood cell production relative to the degree of anemia
definitions_glossary.reticuloendothelial_system: Mononuclear phagocyte system including macrophages that store iron in ACD
definitions_glossary.interleukin_6: Pro-inflammatory cytokine that is the primary driver of hepcidin expression in ACD
definitions_glossary.erythropoietin: Hormone produced by kidneys stimulating RBC production; response blunted in ACD
definitions_glossary.normochromic_normocytic: RBCs of normal color and size, typical early presentation of ACD
definitions_glossary.functional_iron_deficiency: State where iron stores are adequate but iron availability for erythropoiesis is limited
definitions_glossary.soluble_transferrin_receptor: Marker of iron demand; elevated in iron deficiency but normal in pure ACD

pathophysiology.mechanism: Inflammatory cytokine cascade leading to hepcidin-mediated iron sequestration
key_pathways: TNF-α → Blunted EPO response and reduced RBC survival
IL-1β → Decreased iron absorption from enterocytes

essential: Presence of chronic inflammatory, infectious, or malignant condition
Mild to moderate normocytic normochromic anemia
Low serum iron with low-normal TIBC

distinguishing_from_IDA.ferritin: >100 ng/mL in ACD vs <30 ng/mL in IDA
distinguishing_from_IDA.TIBC: Low-normal in ACD vs elevated in IDA

adjunctive: IV iron if concurrent true iron deficiency (ferritin <100 and TSAT <20%)

definition.@value: A hypoproliferative anemia occurring in settings of chronic inflammation, infection, or malignancy, characterized by impaired iron utilization due to hepcidin-mediated iron sequestration despite adequate iron stores

scopeNote.@value: Distinct from iron deficiency anemia; iron stores are adequate but functionally unavailable

medicalCode.description: Anemia in other chronic diseases classified elsewhere

learning_objectives: Explain the pathophysiology of anemia of chronic disease including hepcidin's role
Differentiate ACD from iron deficiency anemia using iron studies
Identify clinical conditions commonly associated with ACD
Describe the iron kinetics pattern characteristic of ACD
clinical_pearls: Ferritin >100 ng/mL with low serum iron strongly suggests ACD over IDA
The sTfR/log ferritin index <1 favors ACD; >2 favors IDA
Many patients have combined ACD and iron deficiency - treat both
ESAs may be effective but monitor for thrombotic risks
Treating the underlying condition is the most effective therapy
common_misconceptions: ACD always causes mild anemia - can be moderate to severe in chronic conditions
Iron supplementation helps ACD - usually ineffective as iron is already adequate
Low ferritin rules out ACD - concurrent iron deficiency can lower ferritin

citations.authors: Weiss G, Ganz T, Goodnough LT
citations.title: Anemia of inflammation

evidence.confidence_rationale: Well-established pathophysiology with extensive clinical and laboratory evidence

sources.source: Weiss G, Ganz T, Goodnough LT. Anemia of inflammation. Blood. 2019;133(1):40-50.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
UpToDate. Anemia of chronic disease/anemia of inflammation. 2024.
